articles.headline: G.O.P. Used Energy and Stealth to Win Seat
articles.snippet: As conservatives mobilized, Democrats paid little attention to a contest that should have been nothing to worry about.
articles.abstract: As conservatives mobilized, Democrats paid little attention to a contest that should have been nothing to worry about.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Adam Nagourney, Jeff Zeleny, Kate Zernike and Michael Cooper.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Jeff Zeleny, Kate Zernike and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: Now at Starbucks: A Rebound
articles.snippet: Quarterly numbers suggested that the company’s strategy of layoffs, fewer store openings and more local emphasis was working.
articles.abstract: Quarterly numbers suggested that the company’s strategy of layoffs, fewer store openings and more local emphasis was working.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  Young people wearing hoodies and chunky glasses are sipping microbrew beers and espressos, nibbling on cheese and baguettes made at a local bakery and listening to a guitarist strum and sing.

articles.headline: Taliban Overhaul Image to Win Allies
articles.snippet: The Taliban are on a mission to soften their image as they try to counter the Americans’ new campaign.
articles.abstract: The Taliban are on a mission to soften their image as they try to counter the Americans’ new campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban have embarked on a sophisticated information war, using modern media tools as well as some old-fashioned ones, to soften their image and win favor with local Afghans as they try to counter the Americans’ new campaign to win Afghan hearts and minds.

articles.headline: If Your Password Is 123456, Just Make It HackMe
articles.snippet: People favor simple passwords, despite Internet security scares like the recent attacks on Google’s e-mail service.
articles.abstract: People favor simple passwords, despite Internet security scares like the recent attacks on Google’s e-mail service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back at the dawn of the Web, the most popular account password was “12345.”

articles.headline: Packing a Series of Pluses
articles.snippet: New versions of the Pre and Pixi can become personal Wi-Fi hot spots, at a price, of course.
articles.abstract: New versions of the Pre and Pixi can become personal Wi-Fi hot spots, at a price, of course.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apparently, the people in positions of power at Palm weren’t completely pleased with the plethora of P’s in the appellations “Palm Pre” and “Palm Pixi,” the app phones Palm produced for Sprint. Palm has now expanded the parade of P’s with a pair of improved products: the Palm Pre Plus and Palm Pixi Plus.

articles.headline: Banks See a Leveling Off in Bad Consumer Loans
articles.snippet: The number of loans turning sour remains extraordinarily high, and any new hit to the fragile recovery could reverse the trend.
articles.abstract: The number of loans turning sour remains extraordinarily high, and any new hit to the fragile recovery could reverse the trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the financial crisis hit, banks have chipped away at the mountain of mortgages and credit card debt looming over struggling Americans. At last, those efforts appear to be paying off, at least for the banks.

articles.headline: Obama to Propose Limits on Risks Taken by Banks
articles.snippet: The president will throw his weight behind a stronger approach to financial regulation, limiting the size of the largest banks and their risk-taking activities.
articles.abstract: The president will throw his weight behind a stronger approach to financial regulation, limiting the size of the largest banks and their risk-taking activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday will publicly propose giving bank regulators the power to limit the size of the nation’s largest banks and the scope of their risk-taking activities, an administration official said late Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Louis Uchitelle

articles.headline: Apple Courts Publishers, While Kindle Adds Apps
articles.snippet: A tablet computer from Apple could threaten Amazon’s Kindle, but the Kindle, which now accounts for 70 percent of electronic reader sales, is getting more versatile.
articles.abstract: A tablet computer from Apple could threaten Amazon’s Kindle, but the Kindle, which now accounts for 70 percent of electronic reader sales, is getting more versatile.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  It’s a formidable high-tech face-off: Amazon.com versus Apple for the hearts and minds of book publishers, authors and readers.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Motoko Rich

articles.headline: Strong Year for Goldman, as It Trims Bonus Pool
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs reported strong earnings on Thursday, but the bank reduced the share of revenue going to bonuses.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs reported strong earnings on Thursday, but the bank reduced the share of revenue going to bonuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one was crowing about their big paychecks at Goldman Sachs headquarters in New York on Thursday. Despite a record 2009, the bank announced that it had set aside only $16.2 billion to reward its employees.
